Although, many people don’t know how to take statements with a pinch of salt and would instead use it as an argument to their benefit. I think a lot of people don’t realise that multiple issues all carry the same importance, but due to a spike in unjust incidents occurring, a certain cause is highlighted for a period of time. People who need to be centre of attention at all times, will then argue that we are ignoring the other problems. But I think that’s not the case. It’s a given that the other problems are just as relevant. But during that particular period of time, this cause is what needs the attention and support the most due to that spike in incidents.

But why do you people find it necessary to make it about yourselves? Migrant worker issues, local racism presence; all this can be addressed at another time. answers.text: @farthehun there's a difference between the social democratic method of treating people equally socially and relationally no matter their economic class AND the socialist/communist method of abolishing class. If you are abolishing class, it requires the  dictatorship of the proletariat... Which is the lowest class of society currently, the working class people who earn by their labour only.. and do labour intensive work. Wage slavery is a thing in capitalism even though slavery has been abolished.... Racism usually happens in capitalism because the noblemen Bourgeoisie creating a liberal capitalist society under classical/modern liberalism requires exploitation of a lower class, so racism is needed to discriminate against one race, so that exploitation and imperialism can be used to loot culture and goods and materials from the people being manipulated/imperialised..

@farthehun Ok racism is way thicker and bigger problem than this. To fully abolish racism and get economic equality we have to abolish class. Which means socialism has to be done.. Socialism is the abolition of class and the common ownership of the means of production.... It can be a mixed economy with capitalism or a socialist planned economy like old North Korea or old Soviet.

FINALLYYY someone with decent common sense

Penguins in Club Penguin are segregated into 2 groups: members and non-members. Non-members are forced to live in plain igloos, are not allowed to buy many items and puffles and are not allowed to take part in most community events. Why is this? This is because Club Penguin penguins are segregated, just like the blacks in the 60's. America's segregation laws would prevent blacks from having many of the same privileges as whites, this creating an obvious divide between the two peoples. This caused the uprising of Martin Luther King Jr, the most famed black man in history, beat only by Kanye. Club Penguin, however, has no uprising. Why? Because it lacks freedom of speech. You step out of line, you're banished. Sent into a permanent exile, an outcast from the Club of Penguins. Any attempt to revolt against Club Penguin's oppression will result in an exile. So not only does Club Penguin enforce a caste system, but it is also a fascist state. Club Penguin is not a kids game- it is quite the opposite. It is a work of a dystopia that has managed to convince its subjects that it is fair. With deep political undertones and a disturbing portrayal of contemporary capitalism, this may be the best work of dystopian fiction since George Orwell's 1984.

text: While I understand the point here, please keep in mind the BLM movement is not solely about racism, but in particular police brutality towards the racial minority.

answers.text: @jarrjarrjarren yea, and its also not pointed solely at police brutality. Black lives lost to gang violence, homicides and shootings should also be part of the BLM movement. After all, they are black lives.

@jarrjarrjarren I’m not sure you’ve quite caught the point of the post fam. It is not to undermine the BLM movement nor even remotely suggest that minorities experiences here are the same. However, it’s attempting to force people to face their own perceptions and behaviours in their own backyard in Singapore before they decide to try and fight for justice in a foreign country(to much less potential effect I might add). Not to take away attention from a truly horrible situation in the US, but this is also an opportunity to take a look at ourselves and reflect on our own situation locally, and the struggles minorities face here too that we may contribute negatively to with/without us being aware. With all these awareness posts flooding our grams about BLM, and not using racial slurs etc. Just before you click on that share button, perhaps it’s worth a thought reflecting on your own behaviours towards minorities in Singapore, your own home country. That may be some change you could more effectively enact, other than that 1 click of a share button on an insta post. But unfortunately, performative activism seems to be ever so popular these days and I think that’s what this post is trying to combat.
@jarrjarrjarren say it louder for the people at the back!

@jarrjarrjarren well said, BLM movement stems from years of injustice towards the POC, yes, racism plays a role here but also their system. They are rallying for peace; equality; police brutality put to a halt.

@jarrjarrjarren also, the degrees of racism here and there are quite different. How many cases are there in Singapore of someone literally being killed because of race? Also, as another comment mentioned, it's hard to 'tackle' any similar issues locally due to protesting being illegal. Even harshly worded social media posts can be considered 'speaking against the government', which is another offense.

text: ....why tho? Of course there should definitely be more awareness and action being taken to address the issues in Singapore, but why on earth would you actively discourage people to NOT focus on a COMPLETELY DIFFERENT movement just because of that?

answers.text: @fantasticrollofjoanna you dumb as fuck. Yea, chinese privillege. We definitely werent targeted by the japanese during the occupation. We definitely werent targeted by british colonist, who actually started the opium war for their benefit. Fuck outta here. Being a hypocrite and trying to divide us further. Maybe youre part of the problem.

@rohanthebodas because like what most people feel here, if you're racist towards fellow Singaporeans why are you suddenly all in for the blm and speaking about inequality. Why are you posting insta stories about having a hard life bc if your skin color and ethnicity when you're giving people a hard life over theirs in sg? If they are being hypocrites, are their intentions right? Is it really because they want to speak up, spark discussions, make a change or is it just a masturbatory act to make themselves feel and look better on social media , making themself look woke about such matters. The key issue here is INTENTION. Bc if your intentions on posting on blm is right, you wouldn't ignore the issues happening right infront of you.
@zoeypyx this post is literally saying “don’t do x if you aren’t gonna do x” which is saying NOT to do one if you aren’t gonna do both.

@rohanthebodas oh gosh... No one said that. The post said that don't retweet or share blm IF they are going to ignore racsim / be racist in sg. Meaning, don't talk about blm if you blatantly know that there racisim and be racist bc that IS being a hypocrite. If you're actively standing up for your fellow friends/ Singaporeans who are targets of racsim then go ahead stand up for them too.

@zoeypyx I understand why you think we should focus on local issues first, but why would you DISCOURAGE someone from committing an otherwise good cause just because they’re hypocrites? The point of this post is saying that it’s better to take no action than to only support BLM, which is wrong and fucked.

@rohanthebodas do you know the meaning of hypocrisy? It means acting like you believing in something but doing and thinking the total opposite. So how can they still be right then? Posting several insta stories can and will raise awareness. But awareness does not equate to being understanding and being able to make a change. You can be aware and still go about the day being racist. This is a deep-seated issue that sadly to say will not change anytime in the near future. So the next best way is to start with yourself and your family members, future generations. If we start from our own homes, in the future this may have a chance to get better for our future generations. If people are racist to even their classmates and neighbours, etc how does posting about the blm even matter? What does it even do? Start from yourself and from your home and spread it from there.

@fruitysnail okay it might be hypocritical, don’t mean it’s wrong tho?? Like hypocrites can still be right, atleast they’re doing it for SOME good cause instead of nothing right. Why would you discourage people against that?

@rohanthebodas there’s no completely different movement if there’s no movement in singapore. also i think the main point of the post is that you shouldn’t fight to stop racism in the US if you don’t acknowledge racism in SG, cause it’s just hypocritical. fight to end racism in the US and in SG. and not one or the other exclusively..

@jimmyyeeee hi! im sorry but i need to just say here that chinese privilege and racism are 2 different things. as a malay, i have been told im smart for a malay and that my english is good for a malay. people get shocked that im a malay with a university degree. on job resumes, when you put chinese, it doesnt affect your chances of getting a job but as a malay, mine does bc my race is viewed as lazy. chinese privilege is also not having to worry about not meeting the “mandarin speaking” criteria when applying for jobs. in many customer service jobs, thats a requirement. when i was a university student and looking for students to tutor, many opted for a chinese race tutor even though the subject they wanted tuition in was non-chinese. chinese privilege is when a chinese is elected president, it’s not bc they needed a chinese president, but bc we needed a new president. mdm halimah wasnt even voted into her position today, it was simply bc we needed a non-chinese president. imagine if we didn’t need a non-chinese president, would she be in power? probably not. probably would be some opposition that isnt of a minority race. casual racism is a very deep rooted issue in singapore that needs to be solved soon, but more chinese need to recognize their privilege and not just silence the struggles of minority races in singapore.

Personally , I don't care cause its funny but I wouldn't disregard others . @rohanthebodas SO IF SG CANNOT MEANS OK LA IGNORE THE ONE IN SG, LETS JOIN THE ONE IN AMERICA INSTEAD CAUSE PROTEST AND PETITIONS WORKS AND NOBODY WILL FIND U FOR LEGAL ISSUES. Right? help la.

@rohanthebodas no one said you can't but there's a rising and ongoing tension in Singapore itself so don't sound so Onz about protesting for other's rights and not address or acknowledge the one in your home country at all. That's all
@sofeazalie we should be able to protest for other people’s rights whenever we want, it’s a genuine cause.
@sofeazalie but WHY? In a country like Singapore it’s not easy to make a change through protest, but in America it’s feasible!!! What’s the issue with being realistic and supporting a good cause?

@rohanthebodas resolve your issues first before you protest for other people's rights. Simple. Don't start cooking if you have not prepared the fucking ingredients. That's what everyone is tryna say here.

@rohanthebodas I think it's good they wanna spread awareness and educate people not to make offensive statements etc. But they do complete opposite of that in real life, on social media they portray themselves to be something or someone better than who they really are in real life. They act as if they truly give a fuck and try to talk about controversial topics to gain traction.. to make people think they are a mature, kind, caring and activist kind of person. But in reality they are barely any of that. Some of them are pricks in real life. Hypocrites can say sensible things but it's pointless if you do the exact opposite of what's sensible.

@rohanthebodas if they were to support an anti-racist movement, yet take no real actions against eliminating societal racism issues, then it makes their activism performative and really does nothing but boosts their ego and pride. i do think your viewpoint is valid, that if the outcome of raising awareness is desirable, then the intentions behind it doesn't matter. but imo i would rather the movement be pushed for by people who are truly taking actions for change than those who are merely doing it to feel like their moral obligations can be absolved just by posting hashtags and voicing their support.

@fantasticrollofjoanna i see that - it’s hypocrisy, but at the same time, Singapore isn’t exactly the best place to speak up about local issues. But still, just because a person is a hypocrite doesn’t make them wrong.. they could be hypocrites, but still speaking up a good cause (which  is what they are doing). I just feel that it’s wrong to hate on people for showing support to a good cause, regardless for what’s happening in their country. Hypocrites can still be right. It doesn’t make sense to actively work against a good cause just because those people aren’t necessarily ticking all your boxes.

@rohanthebodas i feel that if a singaporean chinese actively voices out for black lives matter but yet does not recognize their own chinese privilege and ignores racism in singapore, it's just straight up hypocrisy, because they're acting like they care about racism issues when they don't even care about that in their immediate community. just my take on it tho, hope this explains!

text: The systemic racism in US has been around for a long time. If this racist act for George Floyd was not filmed, the police would have gotten away with no repercussions. Before the video went viral, rmb, the police officers claimed that Floyd was having a medical misfortune and hence died due to natural illness. The video showed that the officer had his knee on his neck for almost 9 minutes and ignored Floyd's pleas to let him breathe. To those who said that violence is not the correct reaction, just try to put urself in their shoes where they always feel like they are victims of being racially profiled, possibly killed in the name of 'justice', and never able to feel free in the streets because the law enforcement themselves are racist in the core. This time they are so much more angry bcus there were evidences of the law enforcement covering up their own asses and normalizing the murder of a black guy. Sometimes being a little bit more empathetic can help you understand how much bottled anger they have. Stop comparing their racism to ours. We have racial prejudices between different races too, lets not pretend that its not there

@tinytrexarm u did? Dont see it tho
@pickmeupdaddy responded to you in the dms :)

@pickmeupdaddy but by identifying the actions/behavior of your own and the people around you, and consciously be aware of the core of such behavior (whether it is racism or not) might help us prevent this learned attribute from passing to others. Yes, racism is a learned knowledge, and we have the power to stop this from propagating. But by always thinking that 'racism doesnt exist' merely shows ignorance and arrogance. Racism doesnt exist for most of us fking chinese because we are the class of the privileged. When i say racism, i am saying that some of us, at the back of ur mind, are consciously thinking of a few very stereotypical voices, which I will not elaborate . Dont u dare say you have not heard of such prejudices. These are is a racial prejudice based on false stereotypes and needs to stop.

@tinytrexarm you talk like you know that the blacks arent oppressed by racism. I think people tend to misjudge people's experience based on their own experiences. The thing thats fucked up about this entire racist issue in the first place is that the law enforcement that was supposed to take care of the people are choosing to weed out, instead, the minorities. Just try to sympathize w me now, ok? Jus imagine the fear of getting racially profiled because of the color of your skin. Imagine the fear of getting hit/framed for a crime u didn't commit because of the color of your skin. There are almost good evidences (check out Youtube yourself) of NYPD police officers fabricating evidence on the scene just to frame black people. And you claim that there are less black people getting killed than the officers, right? Let me tell you why your argument here is flawed: the police officers arent supposed to kill their civilians. Thought of looking at it from that light? How about this; how many black civilians were actually killed by the police? Do you think they actually keep track? Derek Chauvin almost got away with it. If not for the filming of this act, he would have gotten away with it. Simple as that. Now, police brutality is not something that happened yesterday. Imaginr being a member of a community that are constantly being racially profiled for the color of their skin, being constantly attacked by the very society that promised to protect them and having to fear for your lives, your friends' lives and your relatives' lives because of the color of your skin. Also, lets talk about another case that happened that morning of George Floyd's death, ok? Amy Cooper, a white lady, was also filmed for being a racist bitch. Jus go and read the article on it... i am lazy... the essence of this comment here, for those of u that deemed this tl;dr, well, just know that systemic racism doesnt appear overnight. Its is generations upon generations of racist prejudices, taught by other members of your community, taught by ur family members, etc. These actions might be subconscious sometimes

@pickmeupdaddy the thing is you are assuming only black people are killed by officers. More officers are killed in the name of the BLM movement than black people are killed by racist officers. Does this mean racism doesn't exist? No. Of course, it does. Does that mean that George Floyd's death was justified? No. Of course, the officers did a really fucked up thing. However, I do not blame you or anyone else who does support the BLM movement because it is very easy to just see one side with the polarisation of media and poverty porn everywhere. It's not really fair to just say that they are currently being systematically oppressed. One thing I noticed a lot on the blm movement is that they want equality of outcome not equality of opportunity and that's a shitty thing to work towards. But yeah racism here is a lot tame as compared to the us I do admit that.

In Singapore, it seems more xenophobia than racism. The majority favors their own, the minorities consequently do the same with some exceptions. As long as Singapore distinguishes between races, this is not going to change.

answers.text: @coochiexd 😉
@noisesg people really getting mad at you for spitting facts.

@noisesg we don't know what goes on there. Same as how others don't know what goes on in Singapore when it comes to racism. It's not about the race that's dividing people, it's about the past events that are still causing racist people. The only reason why racist people exists is because of what happens in the past. Same goes with religion, nothing to do with race. Race isn't outdated or unnecessary, we still live by our race every single day, it's in our roots. Unless you propose for every country to merge into one, your logic is flawed.

@raypossiablegt Hmmm. I think the US is no country anyone should look at ;-) But look at Canada and New Zealand, huge diversity within the population and no apparent limitations as to how you should practice your religion or behave culturally. It is outdated and unnecessary to have your race on the identification card, in my humble opinion.

@noisesg like what the boy said, race is our culture. Why should Singapore abandon this class? It'll only cause more bad than good. I'm pretty sure the US doesn't have any "Race" class in their identity but look at what's happening now. If not race then everyone will divide themselves by religion which is FAR more worse than dividing by race. We all know what happens if the world gets divided by religion.

@noisesg Removing race also removes the excellent and beautiful aspects of our individual cultures. You propose removing it because you see it as the initial catalyst for a lot of bad things that have been happening for a long time. But the reasons that racist mindsets persist isn’t because we are classified into different boxes, but rather that we have been brainwashed by hateful rhetoric that drives hurtful ideas into our heads. An example would be the use of stereotypes. Teach a hateful race-based stereotype to a child enough times and they will believe that stereotype to be a true indicator of that race for a longass time to come. If we come together and dismantle and unlearn all hateful rhetorics, that’s when we can truly move forward towards true progress as one united people. I Guess what I was pissed off at was that you just ceded defeat and didn’t want to do anything. Idk what race you are, but for many brown folks here in SG, we don’t have the privilege of just not caring... Hurtful stereotypes are acts of violence against my MOTHER. My FATHER. All brown folks that I love and cherish are affected by unjust systems. So if you don’t want to do anything wtv man. Just don’t get in our way thanks.
@oilygrossboy But it is a start. And xenophobia will always be there and class difference, too. I don’t deny this but if you divide people by race you have already set the foundation for it.
@noisesg how naive and privileged a life must you have had to truly think this is as simple as it gets... pls la even without race you got hear about classism? Colourism?

@oilygrossboy It is simply because if you are grouped racially when born then how do you want to change people’s perception? Why can a Singaporean not be just Singaporean? @noisesg lazy want to use brain just say lazy want to use brain. No need to act defeatist all. Can’t even bother thinking up of ways we can affect change TOGETHER as a society. Immediately just assume things will be the way they are forever. Waste time sia this cynic.

Singaporeans think they are equal towards people regardless of race yet practice racism many times without knowing it

answers.text: @raypossiablegt  agree that kids mirror what adults talk and yet theres always a fine line btw what an insult is vs a joke in friendly banter.. adults truly are the gatekeepers of what young minds see, think or hear but the sad reality is the use of a white privilege card even in work-friendly situations. as much as we try quell up these issues with the ‘take it easy’ attitude, jokes aside, have we made enough effort to address them/ educate ourselves? or do we continue to feign ignorance because it does not bother/affect us directly just because... 🧐😕🤔 > a child/ teen can be sensitive to the feelings of others even before the age of 20. its a mindset that does not excuse racist behaviour and if taught early, distinguishes these issues better.

@zoeypyx but I get it, nobody should use race as an insult but again, it's just another stupid insult. If you're still using race to insult after the age of 20 then you're just immature. It's like calling people fat without even thinking about their feelings. But again, it still depends on the parents. Most of my friends I know learn about the importance of racial equality from their parents which is what broadened their mind about how much racist insults can hurt someone.

@zoeypyx insults are perfectly normal and common in friendships. No, I'm not saying racist insults don't hurt anyone, I'm sure they do but they will soon realise that it's just another stupid insult like calling other people fat, stupid or blur. And I'm speaking in a time frame of around primary school time, which is usually when everyone will get their first racist insults. Mind you that childrens at that age aren't aware of how hurtful words can be that's why parents should play their part and teach them what is right and what is wrong. By the time everyone graduates from Primary school, they'll learn that racist insults isn't about racism but just another stupid insult that should only be used in a non serious conversation, like friendly insulting. I'm not saying we racist insults are friendly insulting, I'm saying that it came to a point where racial insults fall into the category of friendly insults, at least in Singapore it is.
@zoeypyx agree*

@raypossiablegt but that being said I after with you but I won't stand here and pretend to understand your struggles or what the minorities have been through and act like I know how they feel. I just don't wish for people to see this as an excuse to continue this toxicity and even worse, go overboard 🙏🏻

@raypossiablegt you said that "racism still exists but it came to a point where it becomes a friendly insult that unites us" forgive me if I'm wrong but I feel that friendly and racism/insults doesn't go together.  Which is why I replied to you saying that just because the people laugh it off and stayed silent doesn't mean it doesn't hurt, doesn't mean their "friendly insults" mean nothing. This is a deep-seated issue and many minorities have chosen to be the bigger person and ignore these comments because like what you said, they get insulted so much that it doesn't affect them anymore which was why I mentioned (sorry if I'm wrong) that it's because they feel like this has been going on for generations, it won't change that's why it doesn't affect them anymore, which I go on saying in my comment that it is wrong for people to make racist remarks and throw "friendly insults" at them using the excuse that it's just for fun or that it unites them

@zoeypyx no, nobody has ever accepted racist insults as "things won't change". People just hear the insult too much to the point it doesn't affect them anymore. Nobody has ever accepted it is as defeat but more of "I've heard this too many times already" and we know that the person don't mean entirely what he/she just said. You can ask any minority right now to list out all the racist comments they've received their entire life and they can list them all out without hesitation and laugh it off. Honestly if you're still making racist insults after 20 years old then that's just called immature, not racist. It really depends on their parents to teach them proper respect and I'm speaking this from experience. I don't know what'd I'd do if my parents don't teach me about the importance of respecting every race equally.

@raypossiablegt it is only a friendly insult because those that are insulted have accepted that things wont change. People say "oh it's a joke" "why are you so sensitive" makes them feel like if they get mad, it would make them seem unreasonable. they have accepted these insults just so that they can remain in the community peacefully and come to terms with the fact that they have no choice but to accept is wrong.

@okifsoever at least majority of the people don't take it too far. Yea racism still exists but it came to a point where it becomes a friendly insult that unites us. Nobody really dares to go anything further from call others black.
@pickmeupdaddy I agree with your point, I was not trying to blame everyone in the country as a whole, but rather saying it is something the community can take note of and work on

@okifsoever systemic racism is smth thats hard to deal with. Step 1 is admitting that there is such racism in the community, both within and outside. Our policies are not racist (btw), its the people that have this toxic racial prejudices towards other races

text: The struggle is real.
Okay, but can you explain why at all?

answers.text: @kris_tan13 as a fellow sg student as well, I see it happen too often in schools or part time work as well. It's more of what shoes you look at it from, not from age / level of education
@haaalizaaa ok im just a singapore student and i dont see this much considering we are all children and this doesnt happen to us much so thanks for explaining

@kris_tan13 i think it’s important that when we want to talk about racism in another country, we need to recognize the racism in our own country first. it may not be as serious as what’s happening in US, but as singaporeans, i feel that everyone needs to work towards being able to recognize chinese privilege and understand that casual racism masked as jokes such as “chinese eyes so small” “malay like to lepak one corner at staircase” “indians smell like curry” are still racist comments that we should not condone. it is hypocritical of us to want to solve another country’s problem when our country is also facing the same problem. they have white privilege, we have chinese privilege. in the context of singapore, chinese privilege is not having to worry about putting your race in your resume. not being excluded from jobs bc you meet the requirement “mandarin speaking” that many jobs on the market need. as a malay, i’ve been told that i’m smart for a malay, that my english is good for a malay, and that it is shocking news that me, a malay girl, has a university degree. while it is important that we sign petitions and spread awareness of what’s happening in US, it’s important to also recognize the systematic racism and casual racism in our own country and work towards ending it.
